Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated Research and Education on the Electro-Mechanical Behavior of Multifunctional Structural Coatings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is an integrated research and education study centered on carbon nanotube (CNT)-based multifunctional coatings. Multifunctional coatings are material systems intentionally encoded with multiple engineering functionalities. The main research objective is to derive and validate the fundamental electromechanical behavior of multifunctional layer-by-layer CNT-polyelectrolyte (PE) thin films. Their coupled electrical and mechanical properties will be tested using experiments, characterized by theory, and simulated numerically across different length scales. First, CNT-PE thin films will be subjected to mechanical, fracture, and viscoelastic tests. A micro-electro-mechanical model will then be derived and validated for simulating thin film electromechanical response to different types of applied loads. Next, the model will be used to evaluate the effects of defects on bulk film linear/non-linear properties, as well as the effects of inhomogeneity of large coatings. Finally, a finite element model that incorporates spatial variations of electromechanical properties will be created for assessing and comparing to experiments their spatial sensing and mechanical behavior. This research will explain, from a physics standpoint, why these nanocomposites possess such unique linear/non-linear and static/time-dependent electromechanical behavior.

The research impacts will be the derivation of new theory, numerical models, and experimental data that describe, in a holistic sense and across different length scales, the electromechanical behavior of these CNT-based multifunctional thin films. The experimental methods, analysis techniques, and models developed are applicable to a broad array of nanocomposites and coatings. New knowledge and innovations in areas such as multi-physics modeling, mechanics, materials science, nano-engineering, sensor systems, and multifunctional coatings will be generated. The lessons learned will facilitate the implementation of future coatings in real-world applications. Integral to this CAREER project is also an education/outreach plan to equip future students/workforce with the knowledge, skills, and business training for them to pursue and secure careers in nanotechnology-enabled multifunctional materials. A nanoscience for sensing course series will be developed. Students from underrepresented and economically disadvantaged groups and female students will be recruited for this new effort and for research. Course and research results will be disseminated via a website, online videos, presentations, and publications.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multifunctional materials are actively studied due to their potential for revolutionizing structural coatings and how they are used for diverse applications. Unlike traditional devices that only perform a specific task, multifunctional materials intrinsically perform combinations of sensing, actuation, energy harvesting, protection, mechanical reinforcement, and energy dissipation. In particular, technological breakthroughs over the last few decades in nanotechnology have brought forth a plethora of new materials and tools that have facilitated new multifunctional material designs. In particular, "bottom-up" assembly by building materials starting at molecular length scales to achieve precise properties in bulk-scale systems is now possible. However, understanding multifunctional materials behave and, more importantly, how they can be precisely designed to exhibit certain performance attributes remains limited.

 

The overarching goal of this project was to develop a multi-scale, experimentally validated, numerical model that can be used for designing and tailoring the performance attributes of nanocomposite thin film sensors and, through this research, train the next-generation workforce (particularly female and underrepresented students) for careers in this highly interdisciplinary field. This study focused on a specific class of carbon nanotube (CNT)-polymer nanocomposites. Previous studied showed that these thin films could be used as strain sensors for various applications, including structural health monitoring and damage detection. Thus, to enable one to better design these nanocomposite strain sensors for targeted applications, this study began with characterizing the physical attributes of these nanomaterials as they are deposited in the film. Image analyses of scanning electron and atomic force microscope images revealed that CNTs take on preferential shapes and orientations that could be idealized and modeled as linear elements joined together to form more complex shapes. Then, numerical models with randomly distributed idealized CNT elements were implemented, and their electrical, mechanical, and electromechanical (strain sensing) properties were simulated. In addition, the model also facilitated the manipulation of different parameters (e.g., CNT density, length distributions, and degree of alignment) while again comparing modeled films with microscope images of the films. Next, by calibrating the numerical simulation results to a particular set of experimentally measured strain sensing results, the model was able to reveal how different fabrication parameters, material variations, and nanomaterial attributes contributed to controlling bulk film electromechanical properties. The last phase of this study entailed the use of this model to design CNT strain sensing elements that would be best-suited for distributed structural sensing, using an interrogation and measurement technique known as electrical time-domain reflectometry. The results showed that a single electromagnetic pulse signal can be employed to simultaneously measure the strain sensing response of multiple spatially distributed sensors connected in series to one another. Overall, the model derivation procedure and simulation results are broadly applicable to nanocomposites with nanotube-fillers embedded in a soft (polymer) matrix.

 

Integrated with these research activities was the goal of equipping U.S. scholars, future scientists, and working engineers with the tools and skillsets necessary for becoming adept and productive in scientific discovery and competing/winning American jobs/careers in the nanotechnology sensing materials domain. At the heart of this goal was to further broaden education and research opportunities for female and underrepresented students. In fact, this project was led by a female Ph.D. student, and the research results derived was the centerpiece of her 2019 Ph.D. thesis. In addition, numerous undergraduate volunteer and Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) students were recruited for this project, with many of them deciding to continue pursuing an advanced degree in the U.S. In addition, several new courses were developed and institutionalized that included results derived from this project, namely, Smart, Sustainable, and Safe Structures (freshmen course at UC Davis), Applied Nanoscience & Nanotechnology (upper-division undergrad course at UC Davis), Sensors and Data Acquisition (upper-division undergrad and grad course at UC San Diego), and Smart and Multifunctional Materials (advanced grad course at UC San Diego). The education and research efforts also led to new collaborations and partnerships aimed at advancing research and workforce development, such as with community colleges in Northern California, the University of Trento (Italy), National Taipei University (Taiwan), and with faculty members in the Department of Structural Engineering at UC San Diego. Research results were also disseminated to the general public through a project website, conference papers/presentations, journal publications, invited academic and industry seminars, international short courses, and participation in outreach events.  

 


Last Modified: 05/23/2019
Modified by: Kenneth J Loh

Unlike traditional devices that only perform a specific task, multifunctional materials intrinsically perform combinations of sensing, actuation, energy harvesting, protection, mechanical reinforcement, and energy dissipation. In particular, technological breakthroughs over the last few decades in nanotechnology have brought forth a plethora of new materials and tools that have facilitated new multifunctional material designs.
